Title: STRENGTH & STABILITY @ RATNER
WorkoutDescription: STRENGTH & STABILITY workout at Ratner 4 sets: 6 min row/airbike/elliptical/stairstepper/treadmill (choose/alternate) Pushups Squats Sit-ups Lunges with decreasing number of exercise counts: 22/17/11/6. If you finish early, begin the sequence again. Be sure to drink water as needed but between sets at a minimum. Feel free to break the higher exercises counts into sets as well, e.g., subsets of 4 sets of 5 or 2 sets of 10. To make it more challenging, feel free to increase the starting exercise count, e.g., 25 or 30. You can also hold dumbbells or weight balls when squaring, doing sit-ups, and/or lunging. Listen to your body and don’t go crazy, especially if you are newer to strength training.

Title: Swim Endurance 208: 2800yds as 6x400m
WorkoutDescription: ENDURANCE SWIM Try to repeat 4x 400m (yd) with the same or gradually improving time (or pace per 100m) and consistent stroke rate or SWOLF (swim efficiency score = stroke rate + time). If completing this workout in open water, aim to simply conduct ~400m repeats between easy to spot landmarks or buoys! WARMUP: 100m warmup 50m kick 50m pull MAIN: 6x400m - steady endurance pace COOLDOWN: 100m easy === NO POOL ACCESS? Try this dryland circuit using resistance band "stetch cords": SWIM STRENGTH 201: SWIMGYM "Resistance Cord Circuit" (12min): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lwUNIp8qkVk Ideally take 15s recovery between each exercise and add in additional breaks as needed. Complete as one complete circuit or smaller circuits of up to 4 exercises repeated multiple times with breaks in between: - 30s Row - 30s Tricep Push Out "Finish" - 30s Internal Rotation (15s/arm) - 30s External Rotation (15s/arm) - 30s Double Arm Pull - 30s Back Fly - 30s Shoulder Fly (stand on cord) - 30s Bicep Curl - 30s Banded Squats - 30s Leg Press (laying on ground, 15s/leg) - 30s Banded Deadlifts (stand on cord) - 30s Thrusters

Title: Run Track 3x1600m MILERS (PACE)
WorkoutDescription: It's time for MILE REPEATS! Perform this "speedwork" interval workout ideally on a soft running track on treadmill. Each hard interval should be at or around your 5k pace - above threshold! -------------- MILE REPEATS: - 2 laps (0.5 mile) warmup jog w/ 2-4 striders - 3x 1600m (3x 1mile) w/ roughly 3-4min of walking or light jogging between intervals - 2 laps (0.5 mile) cooldown job at social pace -------------- FOCUS: CADENCE Focus on high cadence (over 175 steps per minute) and good running form. Visit www.goodformrunning.com for tips! --------------- POST RUN: Conduct ~10 mins dynamic stretching post-run: - Forward lunges (arms up to stretch hip flexors) - Leg swings (side to side and front-back) - Knee hug glute stretches

Title: Swim Endurance 209: 1.2-mile Race Prep TT or 3x 800yd
WorkoutDescription: Break your endurance swims up into longer sets of 500-800 yards or more, or go for a continuous non-stop "time trial" effort or outdoor open water swim. Limit rest stops between sets to under 15 seconds so you can get a good amount of yardage in with mi! --------- Goal: 1.2+ miles = 2112y / 1931m WARMUP: 1x 200y - Warmup 1-3x 100y - Count your strokes, lower the count with more gliding and finishing w/ a flick! MAIN SET: Non-stop 1.2mile Time Trial - or - 3x 800y - Even pace, w/ strong final 50m (15s R.I.) COOLDOWN: 1x 200y - Cooldown

Title: DAY OFF or XT (Z2-3)
WorkoutDescription: DAY OFF If you're not feeling 100% today, consider enjoying a day off! Stay off your feet or simply relax and give yourself extra down time with your feet up (or get some extra sleep/nap time in)! OPTIONAL CROSS TRAINING (XT) or STRENGTH Optionally, if you're feeling well rested and want to get some activity in today, simply conduct light strength training, mobility work, or "active recovery" exercises such as low impact, low intensity swimming, cycling, running, rowing, yoga, pilates, etc. but aim to keep your heart rate at a low "Zone 2-3" effort. After working out, make sure to spend time foam rolling and conducting range of motion (leg swings, knee hugs, toy soldiers) or light stability exercises (squats, lunges, etc.)... think RECOVERY focus!

Title: Triathlete: As you get started...
WorkoutDescription: Thank you for using my training plan. To help you get the most from it, here are a few suggestions and explanations. Feel free to follow up with an email if you are confused (joe@joefrieltraining.com). 1. The daily workouts may be rearranged to better suit your lifestyle. While I've arranged them each day in an order that is usually best, it may not suit your unique situation. 2. Common abbreviations used in this plan: Swim: WU=warm-up, MS=main set, CD=cool down. Strength: RM=repetition max (heaviest load you can lift one time for a given exercise—see Training Bible for strength session details on AA, MT, MS, and SM workouts). Other: HR=heart rate, FTP=functional threshold power, FTHR=functional threshold heart rate, FTPa=functional threshold pace 3. If you have questions about other terms used here, see my Triathlete's Training Bible Glossary for explanations. You may also check out my website (https://joefrieltraining.com/) for details on training methods. Use the "Search" function. 4. Workouts are also explained in my Triathlete's Training Bible in Appendixes B, C, D, and E. 5. At the end of this plan you may purchase another that takes up where this one leaves off by going to https://www.trainingpeaks.com/coach/joe-friel#trainingplans. 6. I really want to see you succeed with your event goal and I'd like to hear how this plan worked out for you. Please drop me a short email and let me know how you did and what you thought of this plan. Good luck! Joe Friel

Title: AA, 3-4 sets

CoachComments: Some abbreviations used in this plan: WU=warm-up, CD=cool down, MS=main set, sec=seconds, min=minutes, RM=repetitions max (the most reps possible for a given load).

Title: SS1. 5 Basic Strides 45min RPE
WorkoutDescription: (This is best outdoors but may be done on a treadmill.) Warm up for about 20 minutes. Then run 5x20 seconds fast on a soft, gentle downhill (such as on grass in a park or other soft surface). Run at approximately 400m race pace (RPE 9, or about pace zone 5b)—not quite all-out speed. Focus on run technique as discussed and shown in the drawings in Chapter 12 of The Triathlete’s Training Bible, 4th edition. Hold back a little on each 20-second stride. You’re working on technique—not speed. Stay relaxed on each stride. Walk (yes, "walk") back to start point for each recovery. Run easily to cool down to complete the planned workout duration. Note that this workout uses RPE due to the very short intervals and walking recoveries.
CoachComments: Note that the daily workouts are in no particular order. They may be done in the order that best suits your lifestyle and energy demands.

Title: AE1. Aerobic Intervals/PDLC 1500y
WorkoutDescription: (You may substitute a masters swim workout.) WU: 100 swim easy, (10 sec rest), 50 moderately fast, (10 sec rest), 100 swim moderate, (10 sec rest), 50 swim moderately fast, (10 sec rest), 100 swim build speed, (10 sec), 50 swim fast. MS: For the first set decrease times with each work interval. All aerobic—easy breathing. 4 x 100 moderate (10 sec rest between). Rest 2 minutes. 300 slow and easy. Form! 6 x 25 relaxed speed (15 sec). CD: 200 easy swim. Total: 1500 OR ALTERNATIVE PDLC SWIM (your choice): For 30-45 minutes, swim 25 repeats moderately fast while focusing on only Posture, Direction, Length, or Catch. (20-30 sec rest after each)
CoachComments: See The Triathlete's Training Bible, chapter 12 (editions 4 or 5) for details on PDLC. Swim abbreviations: WU = warm-up, MS = main set, CD = cool down

WorkoutDescription: Isolated Leg Training (ILT) on indoor trainer. After warm-up, alternate 20-60 seconds with 1 leg/foot only—the other on a chair. Title: AE2. Continuous Swim 2000y
WorkoutDescription: (You may substitute a masters swim workout.) WU: 5-minute swim with your choice of drills and easy swims. Drills: Focus on how well you do the drills, not on how fast. Set #1 scull front, set #2 scull chest, set #3 scull back. (How to scull: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zC7T53Ncjek) 3 x (4 x 50 done non-stop as 25 scull, 25 good form emphasis). MS: Using the “feel” for the water you just developed: 2 x 500 swim (1-minute rest between) at moderate/aerobic effort. Kick 400 moderate effort. CD: 5 minutes of easy swimming. Total: 2000+ OR ALTERNATIVE PDLC SWIM (your choice): For 30-45 minutes, swim 25 repeats moderately fast while focusing on only Posture, Direction, Length, or Catch. (20-30 sec rest after each). See The Triathlete's Training Bible, 4th or 5th edition, chapter 12 for details on PDLC.
CoachComments: Note that the daily workouts are in no particular order. They may be done in the order that best suits your lifestyle and energy demands.

Title: AE2. Aerobic Threshold (AeT) Steady State 1h (30min) HR+Pace
WorkoutDescription: (This may be done outdoors or on a treadmill.) Warm up 15 minutes. Then on a mostly flat course, run 30 minutes at 30 bpm (+/-2 bpm) below your 5a zone (FTHR). Focus on good form with a comfortably high cadence and somewhat flat footstrike (not heavily on heels or toes). Cool down in heart rate or pace zone 1 for the remaining portion of this session. If using a GPS device (recommended), afterwards determine your 30-minute Efficiency Factor (EF). EF should gradually increase over several weeks. (EF is shown on the analysis feature of TrainingPeaks for this workout.)
CoachComments: Note that the middle portion of this workout calls for a heart rate of 85% of LTHR. Disregard that and instead aim for a heart rate which is 30 bpm below your LTHR (lowest heart rate in z5) plus or minus 2 bpm. So if your LTHR is 150, the goal heart rate range for the mid portion would be 118-122.

Title: SS1. Pedaling Skills Drills 1.5h Power
WorkoutDescription: Pedaling Skills. Ride in power zones 1-2 on a mostly flat course (or indoor trainer). Include pedaling drills such as: a) drive pedal straight forward from 9 to 3 o'clock, b) pedal with foot against the top inside of your shoe trying to avoid touching the insole, c) try to touch toes to end of your shoes at start of downstroke. Stay as relaxed as you can while doing these drills. No tension in feet, legs, hands, etc.
CoachComments: Ride only 1 hour if indoors.

Include pedaling drills such as: a) drive pedal straight forward from 9 to 3 o'clock, b) pedal with foot against the top inside of your shoe trying to avoid touching the insole, c) try to touch toes to end of your shoes at start of downstroke. Stay as relaxed as you can while doing these drills. No tension in feet, legs, hands, etc.
CoachComments: Ride only 1 hour if indoors.

Title: T3. Half-Ironman Test set 2400y
WorkoutDescription: Warm-up: 200 building speed on each 50 (slow-mod-faster-fastest). Rest 30 sec. Then 4 x 400 (10 sec recoveries) building speed on each 100 (slow-mod-faster-fastest). Recover 10 seconds after last one. Then swim a 500 time trial all-out. Your average 100 pace for this is your T-time for future workouts. Then swim easy, 100 cool down. (2400m/y)

Title: AE2. Aerobic Threshold (AeT) Steady State 1h (30min) HR+Pace
WorkoutDescription: (This may be done outdoors or on a treadmill.) Warm up 15 minutes. Then on a mostly flat course, run 30 minutes at 30 bpm (+/-2 bpm) below your 5a zone (FTHR). Focus on good form with a comfortably high cadence and somewhat flat footstrike (not heavily on heels or toes). Cool down in heart rate or pace zone 1 for the remaining portion of this session. If using a GPS device (recommended), afterwards determine your 30-minute Efficiency Factor (EF). EF should gradually increase over several weeks. (EF is shown on the analysis feature of TrainingPeaks for this workout.)

Title: T2. FTP Testing 1h Power
WorkoutDescription: Warm up for 15 minutes with gradually increasing intensity intervals as you feel like it. Then do a 5-minute, all-out effort on a flat to slightly uphill course. Recover for 5 minutes in zone 1. Now do a 20-minute, race-like time trial effort on a course with light traffic, few intersections, and no stoplights. It should be mostly flat or slightly uphill (2-3% grade). Maintain the highest speed/power possible for the entire 20 minutes. Finish with a short cool down spin in power zone 1. Your 5-minute average power is an indication of your VO2max power. Record your average heart rate and normalized power (NP) for the 20-minute TT. Multiply your 20-minute NP (and average HR) by 0.95 to determine your FTP (and FTHR). Zones may be set up for the bike (heart rate and/or power) by using these final numbers. For a more detailed explanation of how to set zones go to Chapter 4 in The Triathlete’s Training Bible. This test may also be done on an indoor trainer, but the numbers are likely to be lower than what you’d get on the road.
CoachComments: For the 20-minute test, decide at the end of every 5 minutes if you will increase, keep the same, or decrease power for the next 5 minutes. Warning: Most athletes start much too fast.

Title: AE2. Aerobic Intervals/PDLC 1500y

Title: MF1. Force Reps 1h RPE
WorkoutDescription: Force Reps. Warm up 20 minutes. Then go to a short but steep (6-8% grade) hill. An indoor trainer may also be used. Set it so that the rear-wheel resistance is very high. At the bottom of the hill come to an almost complete stop. Select a high gear such as 53x16 or 50x14. Then climb the hill 3-5 times taking only 8-12 complete revolutions of the cranks (count one leg only). STAY IN THE SADDLE. Your cadence will be quite low and you will have to apply a lot of force to the pedals. Effort must be maximal on each rep to get the benefit. Recover after each by riding very easily for about 3 minutes before doing the next rep. Heart rate is not observed. Power is the perfect gauge of how hard you are driving the pedals. Cool down for the remainder of the scheduled time. (NOTE: This workout is both high-reward and high-risk. Do not do it if you have a tendency for knee soreness. Instead ride in heart rate zone 2 or power zone 3 for 20 minutes after the warm-up and before the cool down. Or if while doing the force reps on the hill you sense knee soreness, stop the hill reps and do a long cool down.)

Title: T2. Functional Threshold Test 1h (20min) HR+Pace
WorkoutDescription: The purpose of this test is to determine your Functional Threshold Pace (FTPa) and Functional Threshold Heart Rate (FTHR) for running in order to set your training zones. Following a few days of active rest and recovery you should be ready for a hard, racelike effort. (If not feeling ready for this test then omit it and instead do what will help you be ready for testing tomorrow.) For this test a road course should be relatively flat or you may do it on a track (preferred). Use the same course every time in the future you do this test. (Unfortunately, most treadmills can’t be calibrated closely enough for the pacing accuracy required of this test, but they may be used for FTHR measurement.) Warm up for this test for at least 15 minutes. Then start the test as if you are in a race that lasts 20 minutes. (You may also substitute a 5km race for this test if your time is likely to be 18 to 22 minutes.) Hold back slightly in the first 5 minutes (most athletes start much too fast). Every 5 minutes decide whether you should go slightly faster or slower for the next 5 minutes. Afterwards cool down with easy jogging and walking. Following the workout find your average heart rate for the 20-minute test. Subtract 5 percent and you have an estimate of your run FTHR. Then use Table 4.1 (The Triathlete’s Training Bible, 5th edition) to compute your heart rate training zones. If using a GPS device on a road course, to determine FT Pace add 5 percent to your Normalized Graded Pace. If the test was done on a track use the track’s measurement of distance covered to determine pace and also add 5 percent for an estimate of FT Pace. Table 4.1 (Training Bible, 5th edition) may then be used to set your pace training zones.

Title: T2. FTP Testing 1h Power
WorkoutDescription: Warm up for 20 minutes with gradually increasing intensity intervals as you feel like it. Then do a 5-minute, all-out effort on a flat to slightly uphill course. Recover for 5 minutes in zone 1. Now do a 20-minute, race-like time trial effort on a course with light traffic, few intersections, and no stoplights. It should be mostly flat or slightly uphill (2-3% grade). Maintain the highest speed/power possible for the entire 20 minutes. Finish with a short cool down spin in power zone 1. Your 5-minute average power is an indication of your VO2max power. Record your average heart rate and normalized power (NP) for the 20-minute TT. Multiply your 20-minute NP (and average HR) by 0.95 to determine your FTP (and FTHR). Zones may be set up for the bike (heart rate and/or power) by using these final numbers. For a more detailed explanation of how to set zones go to Chapter 4 in The Triathlete’s Training Bible, 5th edition. This test may also be done on an indoor trainer, but the numbers are likely to be lower than what you’d get on the road.
CoachComments: For the 20-minute test, decide at the end of every 5 minutes if you will increase, keep the same, or decrease power for the next 5 minutes. Warning: Most athletes start much too fast.
